title: Kuchipudi
hero_image_alt: Kuchipudi dancer performing on a brass plate
short_description: A blend of dance and acting, where performers often sing and dance simultaneously on brass plates.
long_description:
Kuchipudi originates from a village of the same name in the Krishna district of Andhra Pradesh. Unlike other classical forms where the dancer is distinct from the actor, Kuchipudi is a dance-drama where performers (historically men, even for female roles) sing and speak dialogue while dancing.

It is known for its fast footwork, graceful body movements, and expressive eye play. A unique feature of Kuchipudi is 'Tarangam', where the dancer balances a pot on their head while dancing on the rim of a brass plate, showcasing immense control and balance.

The dance combines 'Lasya' (grace) and 'Tandava' (vigor) and is deeply rooted in the Bhakti movement.
costume_and_makeup: Similar to Bharatanatyam, wearing a stitched saree with a fan front. A distinctive feature is the light Kulla (ornament) on the braid.

top_places.title: Kuchipudi Village
top_places.summary: The birthplace of the art form. The Siddhendra Yogi dance festival is held here.

top_places.title: Hyderabad
top_places.summary: A hub for Kuchipudi performances in auditoriums like Ravindra Bharathi.

practical_info.audience_tips: Wait for the Tarangam section – it feels like a magic trick combined with rhythm.
